Despite the development of selective catalyst formulations for oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), kinetic and reactor design studies have been hampered by a lack of data for truly isothermal reaction conditions. Because of the high exothermicity, the temperature of a fixed-bed reactor filled with Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts will show hot-spots with a loss of selectivity. The objective of this study is to measure catalyst activity under relevant reaction conditions of pressure (3 bar), biogas composition (no dilution) and contact time, while keeping the process isothermal. To this aim, we have synthesized and shaped a trilobed Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 catalyst, which may be used as is at industrial scale, and measured its performance in a single-pellet reactor. We found that the presence of CO2 did not degrade the catalyst performance, even on the long run, which should enable the use of a CO2-rich stream such as biogas. Actually, higher methane conversions have been obtained in the presence of CO2, likely due to a possible contribution of methane dry reforming reaction. We also noticed a slow catalyst activation over the first 100 h, while selectivity was kept constant. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Oxidative coupling of methane Ethylene Biogas CO2 Microreactor Single-pellet reactor Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With a view to achieving climate goals, the production of chemicals or liquid fuels from a biogas feedstock is attracting interest as a sustainable alternative solution to fossil resources. It has been determined that biogas production in Europe currently reaches only 2.65 % of the theoretical biogas generation potential [1], which illustrates the value of biogas as an alternative to petroleum-based products. The oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), which offers a direct route for converting methane into higher-value ethylene, appeared more than 40 years ago with the pioneering works of Keller and Bhasin [2] and Baerns [3], and since then, numerous studies have been carried out in both academia and industry to optimize the production of hydrocarbons from natural gas. A wide variety of catalysts have been screened for the OCM reaction [4–12]. It is established that a Mn-Na2WO4 catalyst formulation can achieve promising conversion and C2 selectivity under relevant conditions of partial pressure and temperature [13–15]. In the context of biogas valorization, Shi et al. [14] have studied the impact of CO2 on the performance and structure of a MnNa2WO4/SiO2 catalyst. They found that both CH4 conversion and C2 selectivity can be improved in the presence of CO2 in the feed, even for small amounts of CO2. Gu et al. studied the use of Na2WO4/Mn/SiO2 for the oxidative coupling of simulated biogas containing sulfur compounds, while Michorczyk et al. used a Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst for the oxidative coupling of raw biogas [16,17]. More recently, Gu et al. extended their study on biogas OCM by using Na2WO4/Mn/SiO2 pellets rather than powder catalyst [18]. Despite the development of selective catalyst formulations, kinetic and reactor design studies have been hampered by a lack of data for truly isothermal, relevant conditions (i.e., an undiluted inlet feed, and an undiluted, shaped catalyst). Activity measurements performed with a fixed-bed configuration of Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 pellets show a sudden temperature run-away at a given level of conversion, with a drastic loss of selectivity [19]. The critical aspect of hot spot formation is linked to local temperature increases, which cause hydrocarbon oxidation and damages the performance and stability of the catalyst [20]. Micro-reactor technologies that can better manage the excess of heat produced by highly exothermic the reactions has been developed [21,22]. In the framework of OCM, one noteworthy solution consists in placing a catalyst coating on a metallic heat exchanger [23]. Yet this catalyst-reactor configuration suffers from metallic migration from the support to the catalyst, which leads to degraded catalytic performance. As a result, the catalytic activity and selectivity at the “true” working temperature of shaped Mn-Na2WO4 under relevant process conditions (pressure and reactant composition) remains an open question. In addition, the presence of a large concentration of CO2 in the feed could induce a deactivation, possibly due to an occurrence of the dry reforming reaction at the outlet of the reactor. Long-time stability tests focusing on the oxidative coupling of biogas under relevant pressure conditions are largely unknown. The objective of this study is to measure catalyst activity under relevant reaction conditions of pressure (3 bar), biogas composition (no dilution) and contact time, while keeping the process as isothermal as possible. To this aim, we have synthesized and shaped a trilobed Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 catalyst, which may be used as is at industrial scale, and measured its performance in a single-pellet reactor. Compared to Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalyst pellets, Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 showed higher activity, but lower selectivity. Nevertheless, the C2 yield at low CH4/O2 ratios over this catalyst was higher than over Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 pellets. The trilobed pellets were evaluated in a representative mixture of undiluted biogas (mixture of CH4 and CO2) under pressure, at different temperatures, contact times and CH4/O2 ratios. This reactor technology makes it possible to test a shaped catalyst in the smallest reactor volume possible, which prevents thermal runaway. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis An MnNaW/α-Al2O3 catalyst was synthesized by stepwise impregnation of a commercial alumina trilobe support with a spraying device. The impregnation device was developed to maximize the dispersion of the impregnation solution on the surface of the supports. This system guarantees a highly homogeneous active phase distribution. The catalytic activity of the α-Al2O3 support alone was also measured. Before the first impregnation, the support (alumina trilobe support with a diameter of 1.8–1.85 mm) was dried under vacuum (0.1 mbar) at 150 °C overnight. The concentration of the solution was adjusted to achieve the desired concentration of metal on the substrate at a water recovery volume (WRV) fixed at 90 % to prevent the stagnation of solution in the flask. After the first Mn impregnation sequence (Mn(NO3)2•4H2O, 98.5 % pure, Acros Organis), the obtained material was impregnated with an aqueous solution of Na2WO4•2 H2O (>99 % pure, Sigma Aldrich) and dried under the same conditions. Afterward, the catalyst was calcined at 900 °C for 4 h. 2.2 Catalyst testing A single trilobed catalyst (7.5 mg +/- 0.5 mg and a length of 3.25 +/- 0.25 mm) was maintained in the isothermal zone by means of quartz wool supported by a titanium sheath, which also reduced the post-catalytic volume. The reactor was a tube of 1.9–2.0 mm ID made of dense α-Al2O3. It was chosen because of its chemical inertness and its capacity to withstand pressure. At the considered reaction temperature (>1000 K), a stainless-steel reactor could be catalytically active [24]. The oven temperature was controlled using a thermocouple inserted into the titanium sheath. The catalyst was running under the reaction condition flow of 10 mL min-1 during the heating of the reactor (300 °C h-1). A methane-to-oxygen ratio (CH4/O2) of between 2.4 and 10 was set for the inlet stream, with a constant CH4 inlet flow of 60 %. In the flux, 15 vol % of N2 was used as an internal standard. The reaction was studied at a pressure of 3 bar. The effect of the contact time (W/FCH4) was studied by changing the total flow rate. The effect of reaction temperature was investigated from 650° to 850°C. A mixture of CH4/O2/N2/CO2 of 60/15/15/10 was typically used for the catalytic tests. For conditions without CO2, the CO2 was replaced by He in order to maintain constant methane and O2 partial pressures. The effects of contact time (W/FCH4) and CH4/O2 ratio were studied by increasing the ratio from 2.4 to 10. The Mears criterion was respected, and the appearance of a radial thermal gradient was prevented [25]. The mean gas residence time in the catalyst zone can be estimated at 4.5 ms (10 Nml min-1, 3 bar, 800 °C). The radial diffusion time in the annular zone due to the trilobed catalyst (∼50 µm width) is estimated at 37 µs (gas phase diffusion coefficient for methane of 0.7 cm2 s-1 calculated with the Fuller equation [26]), thus two orders of magnitude lower than the residence time. Therefore, all of the gas will be in contact with the catalyst. Gas mixtures were prepared from pressurized cylinders containing oxygen, methane, nitrogen or helium (gas purity >99.995 % or 99.999 %). Flow rates were managed using Brooks® thermal mass flow controllers. Water, as a reaction product, was removed from the reactor outlet by a water trap. The product gases were then sent for analysis to a compact gas chromatograph (Compact GC40®) equipped with two capillary columns: a Carboxen1010 followed by a TCD for the analysis of O2, N2, CH4 and CO, and an RT-Ubond followed by a FID for the analysis of CH4, CO2, C2H4 and C2H6. A methanizer was used to convert the CO2 into CH4 for the flame ionization detector. Each data point consisted of the average of 5 consecutive analyses. The GC was calibrated for C3 and acetylene, but none of these products were detected. The carbon mass balances were calculated for each experiment and were fluctuating between 98 % and 102 %. From repeated experiments a relative standard deviation on the methane conversion of 4 % was estimated. Specific surface areas were measured by nitrogen adsorption of α-Al2O3 and Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 catalysts at 77 K using a Belsorp mini X instrument from BEL MicrotracBel Corp. Prior to measurements, the material was degassed at 250 °C for 4 h. The specific surface areas were calculated according to the method of Brunauer, Emmet and Teller (BET). Analyses were carried out on 400 mg of trilobed pellets (i.e., approx. 50 pellets). ICP-OES measurements were performed with an Agilent 5800 spectrometer. The Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 sample was previously dissolved in an acidic mixture of H2SO4 + HNO3 + HF to perform the analyses of Mn, Na and Al. For W compounds, the process involved dissolution in H2SO4 + HNO3 + HF, then evaporation and dissolution in NaOH. SEM analyses were carried out with a Zeiss Sigma Field Emission SEM with an Oxford INCA PentaFETx3 EDS system (model 8100). Analyses were carried out on an uncrushed trilobed catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 N2 physisorption and ICP-OES The composition of the final supported catalyst ( Fig. 1) is very close to the desired one based on the optimized chemical composition in the work of Serres et al. [27]. It is important to note that the ICP analysis was carried out on 500 mg of sample, which corresponds to an average of 50–100 catalyst trilobes. The surface area of the catalyst was measured before and after a 12-hour reaction at 800 °C under the reactive mixture. The surface area decreased from 13 to 6 m² g-1 ( Table 1). Hence, it is obvious that major catalyst restructuration occurs upon reaction. ICP analysis was not carried out on the spent catalyst, because one single pellet is not enough for the analysis. 3.2 XRD The XRD patterns of the Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 catalyst before and after reaction and the α-Al2O3 support before reaction are presented in Fig. 2. Three different crystal phases can be observed on fresh catalysts: Na2WO4, α-Al2O3 (in large majority) and traces of Mn2O3. After 12 h under reaction, the Mn2O3 diffraction peak at 33.3° disappears and the presence of an additional phase of galaxite, (Mn0.89Al0.11)Al2O4, on the spent catalysts is detected in a minor amount. This suggests that Mn2O3 present in the fresh catalyst may have reacted with the alumina support during the reaction. 3.3 Scattering electron microscopy A whole pellet was also analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (Fig. S1). It can be seen that the material is compact and not very porous, which is consistent with the analyses obtained during N2 physisorption. EDX analysis was performed on the same trilobed pellet, as shown in Fig. S2. The distribution of the different active species (Mn, Na and W) is clearly visible, although in some places, phases composed primarily of Na and W can be observed, while other phases are composed primarily of Mn. The alumina, which forms the support of the trilobed pellet, is clearly visible throughout the picture. We may suppose a phase change to be possible at these reaction temperatures, as indicated by XRD analysis. 3.4 Thermal analysis The thermogravimetric analyses of the fresh Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 and spent Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 show a very good thermal stability up to 900 °C (Fig. S3). The weight loss of the fresh Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 does not exceed 0.4 wt %. For the spent Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3, we can observe a constant mass loss between 100 and 500 °C, which should indicate the presence of coke (0.5 wt %). 3.5 Temperature Radical reactions can occur, especially at temperatures above 650 °C [28–31], at which radical concentrations in the gas phase start to be significant. In our case, gas phase reactions are likely to occur, because the reaction proceeds under a pressure of 3 bar and with undiluted reactants. Hence, the catalytic activity of the catalyst must be compared with the alumina support as a reference. Catalytic results for the Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 trilobed catalyst and an α-Al2O3 trilobe are compared in Table 2. Relatively high conversions of CH4 and CO2 were obtained on an α-Al2O3 trilobe, even at moderate temperature ( Fig. 3a). At 700 °C the conversion of O2 already reached 31 %, yet O2 is not fully converted at 850 °C. For the entire temperature range, the product distribution consisted predominantly of CO, with a surprisingly moderate selectivity in C2 products, up to 42 % at 850 °C (Fig. 3b and c). This indicates that the α-Al2O3 trilobe allows oxidation of methane and favors (dry) reforming reactions, yet with OCM occurring in parallel. In contrast, O2 conversions are higher for the Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 catalyst, from 24 % at 700 °C up to 100 % from 850 °C. As expected, we can observe similar tendencies for CH4 conversion, with a greater increase for the catalyst, passing from 4 % to 26 % of CH4 conversion against 6–18 % for the support on its own (Fig. 3 a). A clear shift in the selectivity can be observed. The Mn-Na2WO4 catalyst allows a major gain in C2 products at the expense of CO. Indeed, the difference in selectivity is to the benefit of C2 (C2H4 + C2H6) selectivity for the catalyst, since this value passes from 17 % at 700 °C to 59 % at 850 °C for the catalyst, versus 6–42 % in the same temperature range for the support (Fig. 3b and c). When the O2 conversion exceeds 99 %, we observe a major change in the C2 product distribution. Whereas ethylene is the minor product below 99 % conversion, ethylene is produced in majority after 99 %, with an ethylene/ethane ratio close to 2. This corresponds to the endothermic reaction of ethane dehydrogenation at the end of the reactor in the absence of O2. The C2 productivity reaches 31 µmol gcata -1 s-1 at 850 °C. The impact of CO2 on catalyst performance is positive yet minor. Methane conversion is 30 % higher at equal O2 conversion. The selectivity toward C2 is enhanced from 17 % to 58 %. We can observe a higher CO selectivity (10 % compared with 6 % at 850 °C). The ambition of this work is to use biogas as a raw material for high-value chemicals. To investigate the effect of inlet CO2 concentration, the feed gas composition in CO2 was tuned using helium to maintain similar partial pressures of inlet CH4, O2 and N2 tracer. The addition of CO2 does not seem to affect O2 conversion. However, looking at the CH4 conversion, we can see that tests performed in the presence of CO2 show a slightly higher CH4 conversion, going from 20 % without CO2 to 26 % with CO2 at higher temperature, which may be due to a parallel occurrence of the dry reforming reaction. For C2 selectivity, particularly for C2H4 selectivity when CO2 is added to the stream, the selectivity increases slightly. These results appear to be in agreement with the work of Shi et al. [14], who showed that both CH4 conversion and C2 selectivity can be improved with CO2 in the feed. An experiment was also carried out by exposing the Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 to CH4, CO2 and N2 (without O2). At 800 °C, low CH4 and CO2 conversions were observed, with some CO and C2H6 produced. It is not straightforward to compare different catalysts exposed to a variety of conditions in other works, however we can compare them according to certain criteria such as temperature, contact time and reaction mixture composition ( Table 3). The Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 catalyst developed by our team shows competitive methane conversion compared to the works of Shi et al. and Uzunoglu et al. As for the C2 selectivity, it is similar to the results of other works, especially for the Na2WO4/Mn/SiO2 and 1.9 %Mn-5 %Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts. However, we can note that the catalyst from the Palermo et al. study has a high CH4 conversion as well as an impressive C2 selectivity. However, in terms of C2H4 productivity (µmol gcat -1 s-1), our catalyst shows higher performances. Addition of CO2 leads to higher methane conversion and higher C2 selectivity over the entire temperature range. Similar effects of CO2 addition have been observed in other studies. Michorczyk et al. observed a small decrease in methane conversion and an increase in C2 selectivity by addition of carbon dioxide for the OCM of biogas over Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 [17]. Competitive adsorption of CO2 or modification of the catalyst surface have been put forward to explain the effect of carbon dioxide on the catalyst performance[14],[17]. 3.6 Long-time testing Co-feeding with CO2 may eventually result in coke deposition and catalyst deactivation. The fact that the CO selectivity is increased in the biogas model feed suggests the occurrence of dry reforming, a reaction that is very often accompanied by degraded catalytic performance. To study the stability of the Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 catalyst over time in the OCM reaction, a 100 h catalytic test at 850 °C was performed, at 3 bar and at a contact time of 2000 g s-1 mol-1 ( Fig. 4). On the contrary, we observe continuous activation of the catalyst over the 100-hour run time. The conversions of CH4 and O2 increase from 18 % to 22 % and from 76 % to 99 %, respectively. The steady state appears to be reached at approximately 90 h of time on stream. It is important to note that selectivities remain almost unchanged despite this significant increase in conversion. It is possible that in certain published works, the time on stream was not long enough for this phenomenon to be observed. Stable performance of Mn-Na2WO4/α-SiO2 for methane oxidative coupling has been reported in several studies [8, 35–37]. Gu et al. reported stable performance of biogas oxidative coupling, even in the presence of sulfur containing compounds [16]. This was confirmed later over a pelletized catalyst [18]. However, in some other works, catalytic tests were performed over a longer period of time ranging from 20 to 500 h, and in these cases it was possible to observe a slight increase in activity at the beginning of the catalytic test [35–37]. This increase was certainly weaker than the one we observed, but it is still noteworthy. Note that in our study Al2O3 was use rather than SiO2, which might influence the evolution of the different active phases during reaction. The activation phenomenon could be explained by a catalytic restructuration enabled by the high temperature and the reduction conditions of the feed mixture. At these temperatures, one of the active phases of the catalyst can migrate closer to the surface, thereby becoming more accessible for the OCM reaction and improving the conversions. We can also suggest a different hypothesis. As supported by the work of Shi et al., it is possible that the manganese phase could migrate to the surface of the material in this temperature range [14]. Pushing this rationale further, it is also conceivable that phases may have partially melted, leading to a major catalytic restructuration. This suggestion is supported by the appearance of crystallized (Mn0.89Al0.11)Al2O4 and Mn2O3 and by the lower surface area after reaction. We can also hypothesize that the stepwise impregnation protocol (Mn and then W) that was used here did not achieve a very stable phase despite the heat treatment at 900 °C for 4 h. 3.7 Role of alumina support In order to assess whether or not the alumina support might play a catalytic role, in particular to produce CO2, we have studied the effect of the CH4/O2 ratio on the α-Al2O3 support and the Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3. The CH4/O2 ratio was varied from 2.4 to 10 by changing the O2 partial pressure in the reaction stream, while the CH4 partial pressure was kept constant by adding He as a diluent. Catalytic results are tabulated in Table 4 for the lowest contact time and in (Table S1 to S5) for all the other contact times. The plots of selectivities as a function of the CH4/O2 ratio reveal important insights ( Fig. 5). The CO and ethylene selectivities do not vary much with the CH4/O2 ratio. It appears that the C2H4 selectivity remains high (25–28 %) even at low CH4:O2 (2.4). Possibly, a higher yield of ethylene could be obtained at a lower CH4/O2 ratio, because this would allow greater CH4 conversion. However, it must be mentioned that this operating condition is hardly achievable in a fixed-bed reactor, as this would exceed inflammability limits. In contrast, the selectivity of ethane decreases as the oxygen concentration increases, with an increase of CO2 selectivity. Hence, we can conclude that the ethane is converted to CO2 in an O2-rich atmosphere and that ethane dehydrogenation does not occur. Michorczyk et al. also observed an increase of the C2 selectivity and a decrease of the ethene to ethane ratio with increasing CH4/O2 ratio [17]. Higher oxygen concentrations favor ethane dehydrogenation, but also favor complete oxidation of C2 products [17]. We note the obvious catalytic role of alumina, which acts as a combustion catalyst, producing mainly CO2 and CO. Interestingly, the curves of the CO2 selectivity are essentially superposed for the support and the supported catalyst ( Fig. 6a), which seems to indicate that the main origin of CO2 production may be the alumina support and not Mn-Na2WO4. The plot of the C2 yield (C2H4 and C2H6) as a function of methane conversion (as CH4/O2 decreases) further confirms the potential value in operating at a low CH4/O2 ratio to achieve maximum C2 yield (Fig. 6b). For new insights into the reaction mechanism occurring in the OCM, the productivities (µmol g-1 s-1) of OCM components were plotted as a function of the oxygen consumption rate (µmol g-1 s-1) for different contact times and CH4/O2 inlet ratios ( Fig. 7 ). The dashed colored lines represent the experiments run at a similar inlet ratio, and the dashed black lines the ones conducted at the same contact time (from 18,000 to 1800 g s-1 mol-1).(18,000 14,000 10,000 6000 and 1800 g s-1 mol-1). It appears that C2H6 productivity increases when the contact time decreases, regardless of the CH4/O2 ratio. Moreover, irrespective of the contact time, C2H6 productivity is similar, and forms "plateaus," at each contact time. This observation confirms that C2H6 is formed first in the OCM reaction and is then converted to C2H4 and COx, as often mentioned in the literature [38–40]. Moreover, with the constant C2H6 productivity occurring at different oxygen consumption, it can be assumed that ethane formation is a fast reaction that takes place in the early stages of the mechanism and that excess C2H6 from the catalytic activity is directly converted to C2H4 and COx. This hypothesis is supported by the results obtained at lower temperature, where we see that C2H6 is formed before C2H4, and in greater quantity. 4 Conclusion We successfully tested a single catalyst pellet for OCM under relevant process conditions of gas composition, temperature and pressure. The single trilobed Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 reactor achieved comparable selectivity and productivity than laboratory small scale fixed bed reactors. We found that the presence of CO2 does not degrade catalyst performance, even on long run, which should enable the use of a CO2-rich stream such as biogas. Actually, higher methane conversions have been obtained in the presence of CO2, likely due to a possible contribution of methane dry reforming reaction. We also noticed a slow catalyst activation over the first 100 h while selectivity was kept constant. Catalyst restructuration was observed. We show that a higher C2 yields could be obtained if it were possible to operate at a lower CH4/O2 ratio in safe and/or non-explosive conditions at large scale. The single pellet reactor as miniaturized is intrinsically safe and prevent temperature run away. CRediT authorship contribution statement V. coredata.dc:description: Despite the development of selective catalyst formulations for oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), kinetic and reactor design studies have been hampered by a lack of data for truly isothermal reaction conditions. Because of the high exothermicity, the temperature of a fixed-bed reactor filled with Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 catalysts will show hot-spots with a loss of selectivity. The objective of this study is to measure catalyst activity under relevant reaction conditions of pressure (3 bar), biogas composition (no dilution) and contact time, while keeping the process isothermal. To this aim, we have synthesized and shaped a trilobed Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 catalyst, which may be used as is at industrial scale, and measured its performance in a single-pellet reactor. We found that the presence of CO2 did not degrade the catalyst performance, even on the long run, which should enable the use of a CO2-rich stream such as biogas. Actually, higher methane conversions have been obtained in the presence of CO2, likely due to a possible contribution of methane dry reforming reaction. We also noticed a slow catalyst activation over the first 100 h, while selectivity was kept constant.
coredata.dc:title: Oxidative coupling of biogas to ethylene over a trilobe-shaped Mn-Na2WO4/α-Al2O3 catalyst in a single-pellet reactor
